title: Cradle 2 Cradle in view of eco-innovations
segmentation: Thank you very much for the invitation.
I've been asked to really look into cradle to cradle, interview of Eco Innovations.
I don't want to really go into.
I don't know large details, but really point out what are really some critical points which really enable us to close the loop into a cycle economy.
Think the basis of cradle to cradle is really.
Talking and bringing up business elements where we can.
Talk about a cycle economy with a lot of opportunities for businesses.
So we talk a lot about different systems, different concepts, so business will change within a cycle economy in the future.
And eco innovation, I think is a crucial part to really make this.
Happen?
I'm quickly, who are?
We not really going detail.
EPA is an environmental Institute based in Hamburg.
It was founded by Michael Braungart, who invented cradle cradle together with William McDonald.
I joined this organization 2004 as CEO and as well really developed the basis for the Netherlands.
You know, all in the Netherlands, really.
We talk about really implementing cradle cradle in a country in the entire country was one of my job.
But based on my situation as I.
Coming from my home country Switzerland, I realized that in 2009 that the Netherlands absorbed all our energy because they were so much demand in our projects.
But in the area where I come from.
We we just didn't do anything and if you look at this area, which is Stuttgart, Munich, Vienna, Milano and Leondis rectangular.
This is the industrial heart of Europe.

If you look into automotive industry, if you look into the plastics industry, if you look at chemistry, if you look at all different important industries alot of things are happening here and the red points you'll see.
These are already team members that are based as Slovenia is still open.
But I think we really as well looking forward to implement cradle cradle projects in this area.
So we have people from from Gratz, you know them.
Tom Otranto fan ronderos acre.
They have someone in Vienna, someone in Munich, someone in Passau in Salzburg, in the sushi roll.
A few in Switzerland's one person in Lyon, one in Brussels, and one member is in Japan.
Like Japan, because Japan is important in regard of development of new plastic polymers.
They are investing a lot of.
Innovations in plastic compounds.
But what are we doing actually?
What are the main competence is is really?
It's about defining materials, so it's material assessments.
That's a science.
Our scientists, based in Hamburg are doing.
This is one of the major competence is we evaluating these concepts, and if concepts are not really working, we have to search for alternatives alternative chemicals.
So this is one of our court core competencies as well.
Then if you look at material streams.
Material streams do not stop a specific industries.
So our focus has to be throughout all the industries.
And this is 1 core competence, which is quite difficult to achieve.
Then we talk about network management.
Yeah, you all know supply chain management.
But network management only goes further than just the supply chain.
It goes into other industry segments and that's important.
And in the supply chain we have one difficulty and the sync your from businesses.
You experience this every day.
No one really wants to share information because everyone fears that information is going to places where it should not go to.
And therefore we have created our position as a knowledge trustee.
OK, a trustee is very important.
Like a Swiss banker for example, or a lawyer.
He's trustee, but acknowledge trustee is important for industry so we know that knowledge is not going.
Where it should not go to, and this is the position we created and since we have this position, the projects to work much much easier.
OK, so this is one of the conditions which which is important in supply chain to really make it work.
Sustainability in cradle cradle.
I'm probably a little bit provocative.
But what I would like to talk to you is the situation is a different way of syncing cradle cradle.
We could say sustainability is linear sinking.
We have all been educated to think in a linear way.
Alot of you would disagree.
I accept this.
That is, cradle to grave.
OK that sustainability its problems to reduce avoid minimize efficiency.
It's a linear way of looking at it and cradle to cradle is sinking in a cycle.
OK, you are coming to totally different solutions if you start to learn to sink in a cycle.
It's a process that we run through in every every project and in the emphasis you have to three piece people profit planet.
Any cradle cradle you have pleasure.
And why is this?
The concept of cradle cradle is that we don't.
Loose and raw materials.
We have no waste anymore.
We have a huge problem in the future.
Our raw materials running out.
And the second problem is that the quality of raw materials.
Is going to become more and more worse?
So how are you going to produce high quality products if the quality of the products that you're going to develop in the future?
Is of a quality that you don't really want and create.
A cradle has the aim that the quality of the raw materials remains the same over many lifetimes.
So therefore we have pleasure.
So as a consumer you don't have to feel guilty in applying cradle cradle.
Because you know that the raw material using all the products you're using, it's not waste.
It will be reused afterwards in the future again.
I think it's important element as well.
Looking into the educational aspects, how we have been growing up.
OK, the question of guilt.
It's always you should not do this.
We straddle cradle.
You get into the new domain.
And what we're really looking for is we need to.
Define the quality of our products.
Into a different dimension.
And especially we have to look into indoor air quality, the indoor air quality.
Is in small particular 3 to 8 times higher.
In small particular stand outside.
The politicians care about a small particular outside, especially last weekend in Milano.
Man in Rome you are not allowed to drive your car anymore.
That indoor is even worse and we are asking industry to change the quality of their products so that the indoor quality really gets higher.
Look at allergies and everything so we talk about carpets, flooring systems.
We talk about building materials, furniture, closing computers.
So every product that we're producing.
Should achieve higher quality and this is the goal of cradle cradle.
I will show you a few examples afterwards.
How do we work?
We have ABC X categorization, so ABC is OK. X is red.
We have to find alternative.
And great means we don't have teen information to really make the assessment.
So we have to see how can we gather information.
Two concepts we define projects in a way that products should be designed in a way that you're either safer.
Logical system.
Or save for a technical system.
Something happened here in translation.
Not everything is on.
OK, but we hope you find will finish it.
Good probably and a lot of people say, well, you know we should not in the echo D Eco innovation part we should not mix the two cycles.
You should not mix the technical cycle.
Waste biological cycle.
And a lot of products.
That are developed out there in the marketplace, exactly this happens.
And a lot of people asking us well why biological cycle that doesn't make sense.
But we have 4A seams which are important for the future and three of them.
For the biological cycle are important.
One is what chemicals in water?
If we continue to do business like this.
We have a huge problem, so we have to change the way how industry operates with chemicals.
So the quality of chemicals we put into our products and the process is have to be defined in a different quality that they are safe for biological systems.
Otherwise we have it in the water.
The second thing is sewage sludge from our wastewater treatment plant, which is today defined.
That it's toxic, it's not.
It's prohibited by legislation to put back to agriculture.
OK, we can change this incredible cradle and assert is soil erosion.
If a huge problem we soil.
Being eroded worldwide, it's a drama.
And we have.
That's why we have to build biological products so that we can build instruments where we can build the soil back and bring it back to where it's needed.
And 1/3 of the CO2.
Is is bounded is fixed tide in on the top soil?
Therefore we have as well one big SEO two problem and #4 is for the technical aspect which is.
Raw materials we don't like to talk about recycling because it's always down cycling.
We prefer to talk about new trends, maintaining the quality of Prada.
Well, what does that mean from echo animation in the sense of, well, using raw materials?
As well, in a cultural sense, in wrong places, PT is a good system to explain this.
If you use this in the Alpine region, this is perfect because our mentality is that we give away things and bring it back.
We use it and bring it back.
But if you have this in the South and hemisphere where killed different cultures are available, people throw things away, which is OK from the culture.
But it's somehow stupid to really use PT bottles there because they go their land into the sea and you see this areas which are now covering from the different streams into see they are covering.
More than middle of Europe.
It's huge.
An animal sink.
That this is waste.
They can take this is food.
They eat it and they.
Die so this is the wrong material.
The wrong place.
Well, talking about biological systems OK by degradable plastics.
A big thing in Italy or the plastic bags from the supermarket in Italy, by law are in place now since I think last year.
Well, you have to look into what does that really mean?
Most of this raw material is from corn.
That goes into the food chain.
We take someone elses food away.
Is this ecodesign?
The other thing is the material coming most of it from the US.
The corn from the US.
You can be pretty sure is.
Gene manipulated Organism.
Something that in our part of the world in Europe.
It's not really acceptable by the consumers.
And then the third issue is this crying baby.
Means that.
If you really throw it away.
You need about 60 degrees Celsius of temperature.
To start by the grading process.
In a compost heap in our area.
In the outbound countries you reach maybe 40%.
At 40 sorry, 40 degrees Celsius.
So what what are you doing here?
What are we doing here?
So that means we have to implement some systems.
Which can compose this.
This plastics at the level with 60 degrees Celsius.
OK.
Otherwise, we have some kind of a problem.
Bad design.
Well, what is about cradle cradle is and this is really the force that starts the last couple of years is really the community of different industries.
All over different industry segments are really getting together.

And really, market make realizing that the strengths of these different companies are really helping us to really build the market and especially in the Netherlands, I think we have proof that it's really working.
Today we talk about the blueprint Netherlands.
This was our goal when we started.
We started this in 2006 in the Netherlands.
Um, it was a difficult job to do because we were only about 2020 people in our organization.
And we had to test to really help Netherlands to.
Change into a cradle to cradle community and we had two major tasks that we said.
We said one goal is.
We have to.
Reach the point where.
The wording of cradle to cradle is understood.
Where the methodology of cradle cradle is understood, look at the word sustainability.
Everyone talks about sustainability, but everyone talks about something else.
And the second thing was we need examples.
We have to show the difference to the world.
What it really means.
OK, this was our job.
And you see people here.
The lady is the former environmental minister of the Netherlands.
But why do we show people people are key?
OK, people have to.
Take these projects on hand and do it.
That's why it's important.
Otherwise it doesn't.
Work.
We have a lot of govermental.
Regulations starting now with cradle cradle.
Maybe only a few ones.
It's important government can really help us support us.
Support as well to build the frame to build the conditions, but the ones who really have to implement it afterwards is.
The industry is business and are the consumers because they have to be involved in this process.
In closing the loop.
Only a few things.
There is a rich issue of evaluating chemicals since 2007 in California there is a Green Product Act which prohibits industry in selling.
Products which are toxic.
In the Netherlands there is the public, the government procurement from next year, unsustainable products, especially cradle to cradle, will be preferred.
We talk about 40 to 50 billion euros.
In Austria we have to create a cradle Congress in Vienna and Gratson next year.
It will be not in lens.
It will be in Vienna again.
In Switzerland, the government has started this legislative process after Masterplan Cleantech Switzerland.
And it's amazing what happened in my country.
We have now changed our master plan.
Because of the disaster, the terrible disaster of Japan that the focus of Switzerland is now renewable energy, which was totally different.
Eight months ago.
And resources efficiency was not in the master plan.
Now we seen the master plan.

Products and the outcome is pretty severe by the way.

I'm.

We have 4 levels, basic, silver, gold, platinum.
Where do you find well, what is important from the perspective of businesses for the future as well in the perspective of Eco innovations?
The gold level is key.
The key is.
No red substances, so all the chemistry that is in belonging into the product has to be OK. That's number one.
And 2nd for energy.
We said it's not CO2 or whatever.
And we defined this seven years ago.
We said renewable energy is key.
If industry is going to bring in renewable energy, we we don't have a problem and for gold we need 50% of renewable energy, which is a big task for industry to achieve.
And platinum no one has achieved platinum so far.
Platino means no red substances and it means 100% renewable energy throughout the entire supply chain.
I don't think any everyone ever will reach this the next day.
Yes.
OK, this is the certification level.
Going too far, we have a methodology in cradle to cradle.
How we go, how we proceed within projects?
And which is different to normal design projects and what is the difference quickly?
To point this out is that we have to think in scenario chical technical scenarios we have to sync on segments of innovation.
We have to develop product criterias.
We have to make the assessments of materials phaseout, plan of substances.
And we have to start the implementation plan within the supply chain.
Have to build cycle scenarios.
Once we define the cycle is one thing, but to build afterwards scenario how you going to implement it with the consumer?
That's pretty difficult.
Then if you need a certification or not influences on business opportunities and at the end influences on consumer behave.
Here.
A few examples.
Justif key innovation.
Parts from the echo part.
How do we show really the difference?
OK, this is a towel that we presented manufactured in.
Sallent you see here of EOC analyzes this is Mr Weinstein.
The toy you see here with Steve EOC test.
All toxic chemicals here you see.
Near
Nothing.

No, we don't do it here.

The calibration test for the laboratory.
So where you define the testing equipment that is OK and you see there is hardly any difference.
So this is the quality level one to achieve.
It should be edible.
Basically.

Add the test was not based on environmental or ecological aspects, it was just on wearing aspects.
Is it stable in measurements and so on.
And cradle Cradle got second place and as well price wise they were pretty much in medium term.
So that means they are not more expensive than others.
OK. We talk about innovations.

The biological cycle is a technical cycle, so if you want to build stretch materials.
With the cotton fabric, yeah, you have a technical element in there.
You have a technical element and you have to face this out.
A solution is to develop a elastomer material.
Which is safer biological cycles?
OK, we are.
Also it.
Or another problem with my where they have 70% of waste?
And all the materials to plastics are copolymers.
You cannot do anything with this material anymore after being used.
So the idea is, can we develop new polymers?
To keep them in a cycle to bring it.
Or another element was building materials.
Building industry is the second largest industry in the world.
They don't sink in cycles.
The materials are not defined.
So we have here a tiles company from the Netherlands in Maastricht.
They are since 125 years in Maastricht.
The question was can we really?
Our resources are going out from our neighborhood.
What can we really assure that we have raw materials in the future?
Really closing the loop?
And they were really able to define this and maintain the quality for the future.
They have already 98% of their product line is certified.
And now the next step is, can we really be innovative in defining a new glue where we can deactivate the glue after 20 or 25 years?
So that we can take the tiles away from the wall or from the floor and bring it back into.
Cycle.
Toilet paper.
Can you be eco innovative with toilet paper?
What's the designer SPECT?
Well, we have a design problem.
Toilet paper comes from waste paper which from our point of view is toxic.
So we have to run chemistry in our paper industry.
And with this element here, it's funny how time in the Netherlands we have really washed out around chemicals, developed the right chemicals for paper.
Increase the quality.
This industry has 25% of waste.
Because of the recycling, the fibers are getting smaller and smaller.
So you have a lot of waste before they had to get rid of that waste.
Now they can bring it into under industrial systems.
They bring it in in carbon manufacturers for packaging.
OK. Another project in the Netherlands with R and he.
They are have a market share of about 50% of the furniture market for offices.
A company doing ecodesign since nine since early 90s.
It was difficult to convince them that cradle to cradle can really bring them something in addition.
They started the project and all the engineers, the designers.
Were totally shocked because they have never really considered.
The material aspects.
So carefully as it should be within their product design.
They considered assembly.
The assembly that's ecodesign.
But not really the quality of the materials.
Look at the plastic the plastics.
How many plastics are within one product?
There are sometimes a dozen of different plastic components.
You can never bring them into a closed cycle.
And this is the change that goes through these kind of.
Concepts and another one where we really see the good solution.
What really cradle to cradle and closing the loop can be is a company in Switzerland.
Shirah flex we defined the income materials, plastic, steel, aluminium.
According to cradle to cradle, the loop is closed in this industry.
Because if you want to sell a furniture and office chair today.
You have to take the old bug, the old one back so the system of taking it back is is in fact.
But the use is 5 to 10 years.
What does this company do?
They put in every chair an RFID chip, a computer chip with the information of the raw materials.
OK, so then they want to know exactly what information they have in the chair.
And once they give it back, they receive it back.
They knew that they have a raw material value based on the figures of 2010 of 35 Swiss francs.
So they see the business they see.
They really can make the business out of it, and it's really the system approach.
Try gamma, I think a good example.
We started in the fashion business, a composable T shirt that was six years ago.
They are now really going into huizer either going into different aspects.
But they changed.
Their business model a couple of weeks ago.
And the company they built a new company called 2 Gamer Change.
Only for a young clientele.
New clients.
And all these products that they are offering are 100% cradle to cradle.
OK, so and they're going to open a store in Berlin this year or next year and you can order these products on the Internet to gammachange.com.
Chemical industry for the textile industry is really supporting us as well.
We took us about 10 years to convince them.
Now we have one company called Tan Attacks Chemicals which originates from buyer.
They are offering now a system concept of chemicals for cellulosic dyes.
So we have to build system aspects to make it afterwards easier for the whole innovation part.
But housing project started for a technical cycle.
We have one design problem here, which is if you build a technical cycle you need 50,000 tons per year.
If you look at the textile industry, these are all small and medium sized companies.
So 98% of all companies in industry are smaller medium sized.
So how can you build the volume?
To do this?
So you can only build a network.

You have to separate the knowledge and this is what we agreed with Barkhausen that he sells licenses to other companies bring into technology so that we can generate the volume to close the loop in the future.
Key points of cradle cradle.
We have some innovative aspects and main advantages.
One, it's a paradigma shift for business and industry.
It's a quality definition in a new dimension.
We have raw materials in multiple quality cycles.
We talk about a cycle economy.
We have solutions for crucial questions of the future.
At the service focuses more than a product.
And.
Dude, this current stage is that we have up to 80 industries that we have certified already.
Working now in the electronics.
We don't know if that's possible.
We talk about the Blueprint Netherland DNA you it takes it on the agenda.
And we have now a major Business Network that supports it.
And why does business need cradle cradle?
It's the cycle.
Economy is the future and generates profit and risks are becoming transparent and can be designed out.
And I think we're talking about a pioneering leadership.
Ready to Slovenia?
What is happening here?

I think the ambitions here are really immense about the networks with the critical network that you establishing and really trying to support you and industry to really make this happening so that we can really be innovative.
And we believe that the industry here and businesses can be very strong in applying cradle cradle for.
Future and there are two say examples which are using this already in Slovenia, which we've discovered a few weeks ago.
There's a project now coming on and you're building here in Ljubljana and they will implement Royal tiles in the building.
Quite fascinating and as well, I think this quite handsome restaurant.
If you would like to go there with your wife or your girlfriend, they have cradle cradle, Mosa tiles.
So now I'm thinking finish.
Miss all the advertisement and wanted to thank you for your attention.
Thank you.
